questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'Mr Barton was eighty-two years old. He lived with his wife in a small seaside town in England. He had worked hard all his life, and now, well into his retirement, he liked nothing better than to take a brisk walk regularly.'

(i) How old is Mr Barton? Where does he live?
(ii) What does 'liked nothing better' mean? What did Mr Barton enjoy doing?
(iii) What does this tell us about Mr Barton's past life?
questions.answer:
(i) Mr Barton is eighty-two years old. He lives with his wife in a small seaside town in England.

(ii) 'Liked nothing better' means enjoyed most of all or found greatest pleasure in. Mr Barton enjoyed taking brisk walks regularly during his retirement.

(iii) This tells us that Mr Barton had worked hard all his life before retiring. He was now enjoying a peaceful retirement in a seaside town.
key_points: Lives in seaside town in England

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'The daily walks provided Mr Barton with good physical exercise: he was fit and strong. The view out over the sea was what pleased him most. This was good for his mind and soul.'

(i) How did the daily walks benefit Mr Barton physically?
(ii) What pleased Mr Barton most during his walks? Why?
(iii) What does 'good for his mind and soul' suggest?
questions.answer:
(i) The daily walks provided Mr Barton with good physical exercise, keeping him fit and strong despite his old age.

(ii) The view out over the sea pleased Mr Barton most. It was good for his mind and soul, bringing him peace and happiness.

(iii) 'Good for his mind and soul' suggests that the sea view gave Mr Barton mental peace, spiritual calm, and emotional satisfaction. It nourished him beyond just physical exercise.
key_points: Walks kept him fit and strong
Good for mind and soul = mental peace, spiritual calm

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'Sometimes the sea was calm, and Mr Barton was reminded of the happy events in his life. His childhood, his children and grandchildren, his friends, and the places he had visited, all these and more came to mind.'

(i) What did Mr Barton think about when the sea was calm?
(ii) What does this tell us about Mr Barton's life?
(iii) How did the sea act as a mirror to his emotions?
questions.answer:
(i) When the sea was calm, Mr Barton thought about happy events in his life - his childhood, his children and grandchildren, his friends, and the places he had visited.

(ii) This tells us that Mr Barton had lived a full and meaningful life. He had family, friends, and had travelled to various places. He had many happy memories to reflect upon.

(iii) The sea acted as a mirror to his emotions because its calm state brought calm, happy thoughts to his mind. The peaceful water reflected his inner contentment and triggered pleasant memories.
key_points: Thought of childhood, family, friends, travels

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'At other times the sea was rough and wild. Huge waves crashed along the shore. At such times he feared for the safety of the sailors in their boats far out at sea. This in turn reminded him of the sad or fearful moments in his life.'

(i) What did Mr Barton think about when the sea was rough?
(ii) How does the author show that Mr Barton was a kind and thoughtful person?
(iii) What does 'this in turn' suggest about the connection between the sea and his memories?
questions.answer:
(i) When the sea was rough, Mr Barton feared for the safety of sailors at sea. This reminded him of the sad or fearful moments in his own life.

(ii) The author shows Mr Barton was kind and thoughtful because he worried about the safety of sailors at sea when the waves were rough. He cared about others' wellbeing, even strangers he had never met.

(iii) 'This in turn' suggests a cause-and-effect relationship. The rough sea triggered thoughts of sailors in danger, which then led to memories of his own difficult times. The sea's mood directly influenced his emotional state.
key_points: Sea's mood influenced his emotional state

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'Sometimes he thought of his dear father who had died when he was only four years old. How unfortunate that he never really knew that fine old man. All that he had left were a few memories and two faded photographs which his mother had left him.'

(i) When did Mr Barton's father die? What did he have to remember him by?
(ii) Why did Mr Barton feel unfortunate about his father?
(iii) What does 'faded photographs' suggest about the passage of time?
questions.answer:
(i) Mr Barton's father died when he was only four years old. He had only a few memories and two faded photographs that his mother had left him to remember his father by.

(ii) Mr Barton felt unfortunate because his father died when he was only four years old, so he never really got to know that fine old man. He missed the opportunity to build a relationship with his father.

(iii) 'Faded photographs' suggests that many years have passed since his father's death. The photographs have lost their colour and clarity over time, just as his memories have become dim. It emphasizes the long separation and the precious nature of these few remaining mementos.
key_points: Father died when Mr Barton was 4
Only memories and two faded photographs

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'Yes, and there was one large portrait of his father which he treasured more than life itself.'

(i) What does 'treasured more than life itself' mean?
(ii) Why was the portrait so precious to Mr Barton?
(iii) What does this tell us about Mr Barton's feelings for his father?
questions.answer:
(i) 'Treasured more than life itself' means valued extremely highly, loved more than anything else in the world. Mr Barton loved the portrait of his father beyond measure.

(ii) The portrait was precious because it was the only large image of his father that he had. Since his father died when he was four, this portrait was his main connection to knowing what his father looked like and who he was.

(iii) This tells us that despite barely knowing his father, Mr Barton had deep love and reverence for him. The father's memory was sacred to him, and he yearned to honour and remember the man he barely had the chance to know.
key_points: Treasured more than life = extremely valuable
Only large image of his father
Deep love despite barely knowing him

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'During his life Mr Barton had worked very hard and saved some money for his retirement. So, now, he was not poor; but he was not rich either. He and his wife could buy the things they needed, but there was little left to afford any luxuries.'

(i) Describe Mr and Mrs Barton's financial situation.
(ii) What does 'little left to afford any luxuries' mean?
(iii) Why is this information important for understanding the story later?
questions.answer:
(i) Mr and Mrs Barton were neither poor nor rich. They were comfortable but modest. They could afford the things they needed, but there was little money left for luxuries. Mr Barton had saved money from his hard work for retirement.

(ii) 'Little left to afford any luxuries' means after buying necessities, they had very little extra money for unnecessary or indulgent purchases. They lived within their means without extras.

(iii) This information is important because it explains why Mr Barton hesitated to buy the frame and why his wife got angry about the purchase. It also makes the story's ending more significant - the poor couple who couldn't afford luxuries ended up with a fortune.
key_points: Could buy needs but not luxuries
Sets up financial constraints for later conflict

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'He found out that the stallholder was a local man who had fallen on hard times. He was selling a few personal 'treasures' in order to raise some money. "Poor man," thought Mr Barton. "Some people are unluckier than others. I must buy something to help him."'

(i) Why was the stallholder selling his possessions?
(ii) What does this tell us about Mr Barton's character?
(iii) What is ironic about Mr Barton's sympathy for the stallholder?
questions.answer:
(i) The stallholder was a local man who had fallen on hard times. He was selling personal treasures to raise some money because of his financial difficulties.

(ii) This shows that Mr Barton was kind, compassionate, and generous. He felt sympathy for the stallholder and wanted to help him by buying something, even though he himself didn't have much extra money.

(iii) The irony is that the stallholder was not truly in hard times - he was lying to get sympathy and higher prices. He later called Mr Barton a 'silly old fool' and boasted about his profit. Mr Barton's kindness was being exploited, though in the end Mr Barton got the better deal.
key_points: Shows Mr Barton's kindness and compassion
Irony: stallholder was lying and exploiting kindness

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'The frame was truly magnificent! "How well my father's portrait will look in that frame!" thought Mr Barton. "But I cannot afford to pay too much for it. And anyway, I will probably get into trouble for buying it when I get home."'

(i) What did Mr Barton want to use the frame for?
(ii) Why did Mr Barton think he would get into trouble?
(iii) What does this show about the relationship between Mr and Mrs Barton?
questions.answer:
(i) Mr Barton wanted to use the frame for his father's portrait. He thought his father's portrait would look magnificent in that ornate frame.

(ii) Mr Barton thought he would get into trouble with his wife for spending money on something they didn't really need. They had limited money for luxuries, and she might see this purchase as wasteful.

(iii) This shows that Mrs Barton was practical and perhaps strict about money matters. Mr Barton respected her opinion and was slightly afraid of her disapproval. Despite being 82 years old, he still worried about getting 'into trouble' with his wife like a child might.
key_points: Wife would disapprove of unnecessary expense

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'He turned his attention to a particularly hideous green and gold, plastic flower-vase. "How much for this vase?" he asked, picking up the ghastly object and examining it closely. "Three pounds," said the stallholder.'

(i) What does 'hideous' mean? Why did Mr Barton ask about the vase?
(ii) What does 'ghastly' mean?
(iii) What bargaining tactic was Mr Barton using?
questions.answer:
(i) 'Hideous' means very ugly. Mr Barton asked about the ugly vase to distract the stallholder from noticing his interest in the frame - a clever bargaining tactic.

(ii) 'Ghastly' also means very ugly or unpleasant. The author uses both 'hideous' and 'ghastly' to emphasize how unattractive the vase was.

(iii) Mr Barton was using misdirection as a bargaining tactic. By showing interest in a cheap, ugly item first, he hoped to make the stallholder think he wasn't particularly interested in the expensive frame. This could help him get a better price for the frame he really wanted.

questions.question:
Reference to Context: '"And what are you asking for this mirror?" asked Mr Barton casually, returning the vase to its place on the table. "Twenty-three pounds," said the stallholder who was no fool. He had noticed how Mr Barton had been attracted to the frame in the first place.'

(i) Why is the stallholder described as 'no fool'?
(ii) What does 'casually' suggest about Mr Barton's approach?
(iii) Did Mr Barton's bargaining tactic work? Why or why not?
questions.answer:
(i) The stallholder is described as 'no fool' because he had noticed Mr Barton's interest in the frame from the beginning. He wasn't fooled by the vase trick and understood that Mr Barton really wanted the mirror/frame.

(ii) 'Casually' suggests that Mr Barton was trying to appear uninterested or indifferent about the mirror. He was attempting to hide his true desire for it so he could negotiate a better price.

(iii) Mr Barton's tactic did not fully work because the stallholder had already noticed his interest. However, through further negotiation, Mr Barton did manage to get the price reduced from twenty-three pounds to twenty pounds.
key_points: Tactic partly worked - got price reduction

questions.question:
Reference to Context: '"Twenty-three pounds!" exclaimed Mr Barton pretending to be surprised and stepping back in horror. "My goodness! That is a lot!"'

(i) Was Mr Barton really surprised? Explain his behaviour.
(ii) What does 'stepping back in horror' show?
(iii) What negotiation technique is Mr Barton using here?
questions.answer:
(i) No, Mr Barton was only pretending to be surprised. This was part of his bargaining strategy to make the stallholder think the price was too high so he would reduce it.

(ii) 'Stepping back in horror' was an exaggerated physical reaction to emphasize his shock at the price. It was part of his performance to convince the stallholder that the asking price was unreasonable.

(iii) Mr Barton was using the technique of expressing shock or dismay at the initial price. This is a common bargaining method where the buyer acts as if the price is outrageous, hoping the seller will lower it to make a sale.
key_points: Bargaining technique: expressing shock at price

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'Later that evening, the stallholder was sitting at his dining table at home counting the money he had made that day. He had done well. Most of the rubbish he had displayed had been sold. He had made a handsome profit.'

(i) How did the stallholder feel about his day's sales?
(ii) What does calling his goods 'rubbish' reveal about him?
(iii) What does 'handsome profit' mean?
questions.answer:
(i) The stallholder felt pleased with his day's sales. He had done well and made a handsome profit by selling most of his items.

(ii) Calling his goods 'rubbish' reveals that the stallholder was dishonest and contemptuous of his customers. He knew his items were worthless junk but sold them as if they were valuable. This shows his cynical, exploitative nature.

(iii) 'Handsome profit' means a substantial or impressive profit - more money than expected. The stallholder had earned significantly more than his items were worth.

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'He said to his wife: "Oh! by the way. You know that old mirror we bought for two pounds at a junk shop last year? Well, I sold it for twenty pounds today!"'

(i) How much had the stallholder actually paid for the mirror? What profit did he make?
(ii) What does this reveal about the stallholder's character?
(iii) How does this create irony in the story?
questions.answer:
(i) The stallholder had paid only two pounds for the mirror at a junk shop. He sold it for twenty pounds, making a profit of eighteen pounds.

(ii) This reveals that the stallholder was a shrewd but dishonest businessman. He had lied about falling on hard times to gain sympathy and get higher prices. He was actually doing very well financially through his deceptive practices.

(iii) This creates irony because the stallholder thinks he has cleverly cheated Mr Barton. He doesn't know that hidden in the frame was a painting worth nearly half a million pounds. The person he called a 'fool' will actually become very wealthy from this purchase.
key_points: Dramatic irony: hidden painting worth fortune

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'The stallholder's wife smiled. "How wonderful!" she exclaimed. The stallholder beamed with pride. "Some people will buy any old rubbish," he said, "Especially when you tell them a sad story! Silly old fool, that man."'

(i) What does 'beamed' mean? What did the stallholder think of Mr Barton?
(ii) What does 'some people will buy any old rubbish' suggest?
(iii) Why is calling Mr Barton a 'silly old fool' deeply ironic?
questions.answer:
(i) 'Beamed' means smiled brightly with pride. The stallholder thought Mr Barton was a 'silly old fool' who had been tricked by his sad story about hard times.

(ii) 'Some people will buy any old rubbish' suggests the stallholder's contempt for his customers. He believed people were gullible and easily fooled, especially when given a sympathetic story.

(iii) Calling Mr Barton a 'silly old fool' is deeply ironic because Mr Barton will discover a painting worth nearly half a million pounds hidden in the frame. The stallholder, who thought he was so clever, actually sold a fortune for just twenty pounds. He is the real fool in this story.
key_points: Irony: stallholder is the real fool

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'Earlier that day, when he had returned from his walk, Mr Barton had told his wife what he had bought. She had become very angry and had taken herself off to bed. She often did this when she was cross or upset about something. "If you can spend money on an old frame, you can go out and buy your own dinner!" she had shouted, before storming off.'

(i) How did Mrs Barton react to the purchase? Why?
(ii) What does 'taken herself off to bed' tell us about Mrs Barton?
(iii) What does 'storming off' mean?
questions.answer:
(i) Mrs Barton was very angry about the purchase. She went off to bed and shouted that he could buy his own dinner. She was upset because they had limited money and the frame seemed like an unnecessary expense.

(ii) 'Taken herself off to bed' tells us that Mrs Barton often expressed her displeasure by withdrawing. This was her way of showing anger or upset - she would isolate herself rather than continue arguing.

(iii) 'Storming off' means leaving angrily and dramatically. Mrs Barton left the room in a huff, showing her strong disapproval of her husband's purchase.
key_points: Withdrawing to bed as expression of displeasure

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'In a few minutes the back was loose. He lifted it off expecting to see the mirror, but to his surprise he found a sheet of canvas between the wooden back and the mirror. He turned the canvas over and laid it out flat next to the mirror in its frame.'

(i) What did Mr Barton find behind the mirror?
(ii) Why was he surprised?
(iii) What is a canvas typically used for?
questions.answer:
(i) To his surprise, Mr Barton found a sheet of canvas (a painting) hidden between the wooden back and the mirror.

(ii) He was surprised because he expected to see just the mirror when he removed the back. He didn't expect anything to be hidden between the mirror and the wooden backing.

(iii) A canvas is typically used as a surface for oil paintings. Artists paint on stretched canvas fabric. Finding a canvas behind the mirror suggested there was a hidden painting.

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'He studied the canvas. There before him was a remarkable scene. It was an oil painting of a shepherd with his flock resting under the shade of a large oak tree. Far in the distance, there was what looked like a small village, but the details were not clear. The painting was old and covered in grime.'

(i) Describe the painting that Mr Barton discovered.
(ii) What does 'remarkable' suggest about the painting?
(iii) What does 'covered in grime' tell us about the painting's history?
questions.answer:
(i) The painting was an oil painting showing a shepherd with his flock of sheep resting under a large oak tree. In the distance was a small village, though the details were unclear. The painting was old and dirty.

(ii) 'Remarkable' suggests that the painting was impressive, noteworthy, and striking. Even covered in dirt, something about the scene caught Mr Barton's attention as special or extraordinary.

(iii) 'Covered in grime' tells us the painting had been hidden away for a very long time. Grime (dirt and dust) had accumulated over many years, suggesting the painting had been forgotten and neglected, hidden behind the mirror for possibly decades or centuries.
key_points: Shepherd with flock under oak tree
Covered in grime = hidden for long time

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'The following day, Mr Barton walked up and down but could find no sign of the stall or the stallholder. He walked home slowly, quite afraid of what his wife might say. But she was in a better mood that day, and she did not shout at him when he returned with the mirror.'

(i) Why couldn't Mr Barton return the mirror?
(ii) Why was Mr Barton afraid to go home?
(iii) How had Mrs Barton's mood changed?
questions.answer:
(i) Mr Barton couldn't return the mirror because the stallholder and his stall had disappeared. He could find no sign of them anywhere, so returning the item was impossible.

(ii) Mr Barton was afraid to go home because he thought his wife would still be angry about the purchase. Since he couldn't get a refund, he feared she would scold him again.

(iii) Mrs Barton was in a better mood and didn't shout at him. She said 'Never mind' and appreciated that he had at least tried to get their money back. She had calmed down overnight.

questions.question:
Reference to Context: '"About two hundred years ago, many famous painters had their paintings framed in frames just like this one," explained the manager. "The frames are very valuable today, but of course, the paintings that were in them are much more valuable!"'

(i) What did the manager explain about old frames?
(ii) What did this information suggest about Mr Barton's painting?
(iii) Why is this moment significant in the story?
questions.answer:
(i) The manager explained that about two hundred years ago, famous painters used frames like the one Mr Barton had bought. While the frames themselves are valuable today, the paintings that were originally in them are much more valuable.

(ii) This information suggested that the painting Mr Barton found hidden behind the mirror might be extremely valuable. If the frame was used by famous painters, the hidden painting could be a lost masterpiece.

(iii) This moment is significant because it begins to reveal the true value of Mr Barton's discovery. The manager's explanation builds suspense and hints that Mr Barton may have found something extraordinarily valuable.
key_points: Old frames used by famous painters

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'The manager of the art gallery studied the painting carefully. "If I am not mistaken," he said excitedly, "this is a very famous painting, by a very famous artist and it is worth a very, very, large sum of money!"'

(i) What does 'if I am not mistaken' mean? What did the manager discover?
(ii) Why was the manager excited?
(iii) What does the repetition of 'very' emphasize?
questions.answer:
(i) 'If I am not mistaken' means 'if I am correct' - expressing polite certainty. The manager discovered that the painting was very famous, by a famous artist, and worth an enormous sum of money.

(ii) The manager was excited because he recognized the painting as something exceptional. For an art gallery manager, discovering a lost masterpiece would be a thrilling professional experience.

(iii) The repetition of 'very' emphasizes just how valuable the painting was. 'Very famous', 'very famous artist', and 'very, very, large sum of money' all stress the extraordinary nature of the discovery. The double 'very' before 'large sum' particularly underscores the enormous value.
key_points: If I am not mistaken = expressing certainty

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'Mrs and Mr Barton stood and stared at the manager for a long time. Then they held each other's hands and danced. The manager smiled.'

(i) How did Mr and Mrs Barton react to the news?
(ii) What does 'held each other's hands and danced' symbolize?
(iii) Why did the manager smile?
questions.answer:
(i) Mr and Mrs Barton were stunned and stared at the manager for a long time. Then, overwhelmed with joy, they held hands and danced together.

(ii) 'Held each other's hands and danced' symbolizes their overwhelming joy and celebration. It also shows the strength of their marriage - despite their earlier argument about the purchase, they now celebrate together. Their spontaneous dance represents pure happiness.

(iii) The manager smiled because he was happy to witness their joy. He had just delivered life-changing news to this elderly couple, and seeing their delighted reaction would bring pleasure to anyone. It was a heartwarming moment.
key_points: Dancing symbolizes joy and strong marriage
Manager happy to see their reaction

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'The oil painting, in its original frame, was sold at auction for nearly half a million pounds.'

(i) How much was the oil painting sold for?
(ii) What is the irony at the end of the story?
(iii) What moral lesson does this ending teach?
questions.answer:
(i) The oil painting, in its original frame, was sold at auction for nearly half a million pounds.

(ii) The irony is that the stallholder called Mr Barton a 'silly old fool' for buying 'rubbish' for twenty pounds. But Mr Barton discovered a painting worth nearly half a million pounds, making the stallholder the real fool who missed out on a fortune.

(iii) The ending teaches several moral lessons: kindness and honesty are rewarded; those who try to cheat others often end up losing themselves; true value is not always obvious; and good things come to those with good intentions. Mr Barton's generous nature led to his good fortune.
key_points: Sold for nearly half a million pounds

questions.question:
Reference to Context: 'Some while later, the portrait of Mr Barton's father hung proudly on the wall in Mr Barton's small study next to the dining room. It was in a new frame very much like the one Mr Barton had bought from the stallholder.'

(i) What happened to Mr Barton's father's portrait?
(ii) Why was Mr Barton able to get a similar frame now?
(iii) What does this ending show about what was most important to Mr Barton?
questions.answer:
(i) The portrait of Mr Barton's father hung proudly on the wall in his small study. It was placed in a new frame similar to the one from the stallholder.

(ii) Mr Barton could now afford a similar frame because he had become wealthy from selling the hidden painting. The nearly half million pounds gave him financial freedom to buy whatever he wanted.

(iii) This ending shows that despite becoming wealthy, what mattered most to Mr Barton was honouring his father's memory. His original goal - to frame his father's portrait beautifully - was achieved. The money was secondary to his emotional connection with his late father.
key_points: Wealthy enough to buy similar frame
